@/tuto000-introduction.description: An introduction to the tutorial and guide

Sy3bms2Lv.content:
**Welcome to No-Code Programming for Biology!**
*This tutorial is designed to accompany the Open Plant Biomaker No-Code Programming for Biology Beginner's Guide.* 

It will introduce you to the basics of using XOD as well as some simple hardware. Our beginner's guide uses the [Grove All-in-one Beginner Kit for Arduino](https://www.seeedstudio.com/Grove-Beginner-Kit-for-Arduino-p-4549.html?gclid=Cj0KCQjw8fr7BRDSARIsAK0Qqr48EzQQLHNapejVpJZq7i0NiSxg0TG0_Ephxa3OaHbeetzX-EmHb0caAqpqEALw_wcB), but can also be adapted for other Arduino-based microcontrollers.

If you haven't done so already, we advise dowloading the Beginner's Guide from the [Biomaker website](https://www.biomaker.org/nocode-programming-for-biology-handbook) and reading through 'Lesson 1: Introduction' and (p2-15) the start of 'Lesson 2: Getting Started' (p18-19). This will provide some useful background information to help you with the tasks in this tutorial.

You can complete this tutorial by opening and working through each of the patches in turn. These can be found in the Project Browser, at the top left of the screen.

An index describing each patch and listing the hardware and nodes used in each patch can be found at the end of the tutorial (tuto998), along with a 'cheatsheet' describing the basic settings to use each of the devices on the Grove board (tuto999).

*When you're ready let's start with Task 1: Testing Your Board, by opening 'tuto101-testing-your-board'...*

@/tuto999-grove-board-cheat-sheet.description:
Grove Board Cheat Sheet.
This cheat-sheet provides a quick guide to which XOD node and settings to use for each of the inbuilt components on the Grove All-In-One Beginner Kit for Arduino.

SynA6-Ped.content:
**1. LED**

*Node*
`xod/common-hardware/led `

*Settings*
PORT = D4 
LUM = luminance (brightness) between 0-1 
ACT = True 

*Used in*
tuto1xx
tuto4xx

HJ1GAZDeu.content: This cheat-sheet provides a quick guide to which XOD node to use for each of the inbuilt components on the Grove All-In-One Beginner Kit for Arduino. The guide suggests a node for each component as well as some standard settings. Other nodes and settings can also be used, and encourage playing around with node settings and searching for new nodes.

HktykGDgd.content:
**2. Buzzer**

*Node*
`marcoaita/malibrary/buzzer `

*Settings*
PORT = D5 
EN = True 
FREQ = 440 

*Used in*
tuto2xx
tuto9xx

B1FHJzDg_.content:
**3. OLED Screen (SSD1306)**

*Nodes*
`wayland/ssd1306-oled-i2c/ssd1306-oled-i2c-device`
`wayland/ssd1306-oled-i2c/clear-display`
`wayland/ssd1306-oled-i2c/send-buffer-to-display `

*Settings*
ADDRESS = 3Ch 
WEIGHT = 128 
HEIGHT = 64 
RESET = -1

*Notes*
Add any other nodes from wayland/ssd1306-oled-i2c 		between `clear-display` and `send-buffer-to-display`.
Connect `ssd1306-oled-i2c-device` DEV to all DEV pins.
Connect `clock` node to `clear-display` UPD then connect 	each UPD pin in turn. 

*Used in*
tuto6xx
tuto7xx
tuto8xx

SJ-PgGPeu.content:
**4. Button**

*Node*
`xod/common-hardware/button`

*Settings*
PORT = D6 
UPD = Loop

*Notes*
`button` is automatically on and turns off with a press. 	Use a `not` node to invert this.

*Used in*
tuto2xx

@/tuto998-index.description: This patch provides an index of each task in this tutorial, including what nodes and hardware are used, and what steps are taken in each patch.

@/tuto101-testing-your-board-adding-a-no.description:
Start of Task 1: Testing Your Board.
This task will walk you through how to how to connect your board to the computer and upload your first programme using XOD. It will use the LED and button modules of the Grove board.
T1 Step 1: Adding a Node

SJxEwnoT8w.content:
*Now that you’ve downloaded the software you’re all set and ready to get stuck in! *

*This task will walk you through how to how to connect your board to the computer and upload your first programme using XOD.  *

We’ll be using the LED light in the top left corner of the board to test our connection.  

You may notice that when you first plug in the board the OLED screen in the middle-left turns on. This is part of the inbuilt demo mode on the board. You can learn more about this in the [Grove User Manual](https://files.seeedstudio.com/wiki/Grove-Beginner-Kit-For-Arduino/res/Grove-Beginner-Kit-For-ArduinoPDF.pdf).

rJVvni6Uw.content:
*Let's start by adding a node to this patch.*

To do this, find the xod/common-hardware library in the Project Browser on the left. Click the dropdown menu and find the node called *“led”*.  Click on this node and drag it into the patch.

SkpsUZPgO.content: **Before starting the task, we suggest reading the introduction to this guide 'Lesson 1: Introduction' (p2-15) and the start of 'Lesson 2: Getting Started' (p18-19) in the Beginner's Guide ([Download here](https://www.biomaker.org/nocode-programming-for-biology-handbook/#grove)).**

@/tuto102-adding-a-node-alternative-meth.description: T1 Step 2:  Adding a Node (alternative methods)

BJe7rn2Uw.content:
*1. Drag from Libraries* 

As you did in tuto101. If you know the library the node is in, you can find the library in the Project Browser, click the 			dropdown menu, click on the node, drag it into the patch and release.

Hk0jP22Uw.content:
**Task 1: Testing Your Board**
*Adding a Node (alternative methods)*

HkCJS3hLD.content:
*Great!*

There are also several other ways of adding a node in XOD. Let's try them out too.

rJDuHhh8v.content:
*2. Double Click on the Patch* 

If you know the name of the node you want, or want to search for a node you can use the search bar. Double click anywhere in your patch and the search bar will appear. Start typing the name of the node and options will appear. Click on the correct node and it will insert into your patch.

*Test this out by double clicking on the patch and typing 'led' to insert an led node.*

rJSjU33Uv.content:
*4. Menu Bar *

This is a third way to bring up the search bar. Select ‘Edit > Insert Node...’ from the menu bar.

*Test this out by selecting 'Edit > Insert Node...'. Then type 'led' to insert an led node.*

rkx4UhhIP.content:
*3. Keyboard Shortcut* 

Similar to double-clicking the patch. Click anywhere on the patch and press ‘i’ on your keyboard. This will bring up the 		same search bar as above.

*Test this out by clicking on the patch and typing 'i'. Then type 'led' to insert an led node.*

HyWvO2hLw.content:
*1. The PORT Pin*

The LED on the board is connected to port D4, so click on the text box next to PORT and set this to D4 by typing ‘D4’.

S1wsu23IP.content:
*2. The LUM Pin*

LUM stands for luminance, i.e. how bright is the LED is on a scale of 0-1. Set this to 1 (brightest level) by typing ‘1’.

SyfZd328v.content:
*Now let's change the node's pin parameters*

Click on the led node. The outer edge will turn blue and more information will appear in the Inspector pane on the bottom left.

ryTpd2hUD.content:
*3. The ACT Pin*

ACT is a boolean pin that can only be true or false. Use the dropdown to set this to ‘True’. This makes sure the LED responds.

HyLw323Iw.content:
Click on the small lightening icon in the bottom right, or select ‘Deploy > Upload to Arduino...’ from the menu bar.

**Then watch your board to see what happens!**

SydP5hh8D.content:
*If you haven't plugged your board in already, do so now.*

When you upload the patch a screen will pop up for you to set the board model and serial port.

Use the dropdown menu below *Board Model* to select *‘Arduino Uno’ or ‘Arduino/Genion Uno’*.

Use the dropdown menu below *Serial Port* to select *‘dev/tty.usbserial-0001 (Silicon Labs)’*.

rJgj7Y3nIw.content:
*Time to upload!*

You should have ended up with an led like the one displayed on the right, with the correct pin settings displayed above the circles.

HJisJpnLP.content:
*Still need help?*

XOD provides watch and tweak nodes which are useful for troubleshooting and debugging your programme. Learn more about them in tuto301, or take a look at [XOD’s guide to debugging](https://xod.io/docs/guide/debugging/). For further help you can always contact the Biomaker team at synbio@hermes.cam.ac.uk.

HkLWCnh8D.content:
*3. Have you uploaded using the right board model and serial port?*

 After you click the upload button you should make sure that you have the correct board model and serial port selected. Use the dropdown menus to select ‘Arduino Uno’/’Arduino/Genion Uno’ and ‘dev/tty.usbserial-0001 (Silicon Labs)’.

SJ4o03n8P.content:
*3. Do you need to install a USB driver?*

To communicate with the board you will need to have a CP210 USB driver installed. Most operating systems will have this installed already, but if you're having trouble (e.g. XOD is not recognising your board) you can download the driver from the [Silabs website](www.silabs.com/products/development-tools/software/usb-to-uart-bridge-vcp-drivers).

SkGd622LD.content:
*1. Is the board plugged in correctly? *

If your board is plugged in correctly the power light  on the right side of the seeeduino module should light up. If not, 			make sure that the USB cable is plugged in fully.

r1WjphhLw.content:
*2. Have you set your node parameters correctly?* 

Setting the wrong parameters is a common mistake. In this case you should make sure the pins are set as follows:  PORT = D4, LUM = 1, ACT = True

ry24phh8D.content:
*If you are having trouble uploading your programme, don't worry, there's a few simple things you can try!*

If everything is working fine, feel free to carry on to tuto106.

ryWp6H-Kv.content:
*Great! Now let’s expand our patch by adding another node.*

We will use a button node so that we can switch the led on and off at will.

Using one of the ways described in tuto102, add a button node from the xod/common-hardware library.

BJgsb0SWtP.content:
*Now we need to set the pins for this new node.*

*1. PORT*

As with the LED node, PORT specifies which port the button is connected to. Set this to ‘D6’.

*2. UPD*

The UPD pin specifies how often the programme updates. This can be set to ‘Never’, ‘On Boot (Boot)’, or ‘Continuously (Loop)’.

Alternatively another node can be connected to this pin and used to determine how often it updates.

Make sure this is set to ‘Continuously (Loop)’, so that whenever we press the button it is read instantly.

rJZZx1IZYD.content:
*Next, we need to connect the two nodes by creating a link between them.*

We want the led to turn on whenever we press the button, so we need to connect the button output pin PRS (press) to the led input pin LUM.

Do this by clicking on the PRS pin and then on the LUM pin. A line will appear between them.

Note that, now when you click on the led node you will not be able to set the LUM pin, because it’s value is determined by button node.

@/tuto109-upload-your-patch-and-test.description: T1 Step 9: Upload Your Patch and Test the Button

ByM53y8WFD.content:
**Task 1: Testing Your Board**
*Upload Your Patch and Test the Button*

S1WcnkUbKP.content:
*Now let's test our expanded patch by uploading it to the board again.*

Upload the patch using the little lightening upload button and see what happens.

You will notice that the programme is backwards. The LED is on and turns off when you press it.

This is because the board’s buttons are set to be on by default, and turn off when pressed.

We can fix this programme with a logic node.

@/tuto110-add-a-not-node.description: T1 Step 10: Add a Not Node

BJXj3mLZYD.content:
**Task 1: Testing Your Board**
*Add a Not Node*

Syfj3XUbKw.content:
*To invert the signal from the button we can use a different type of node that represent a logic function, rather than a piece of hardware.*

Insert a not node from the xod/core library.

BJqoN8WFv.content:
*Then we can re-test the patch.*

Now try uploading your programme again. This time it should work as planned.

SyMuHE8btv.content:
*We need to rewire the patch to incude the not node between the button and led.*

Delete the link between the button and led. Connect PRS to the not input pin, and the not output pin to LUM.

You can move the nodes around to help visualise the flow of the programme if it helps.

BkrztrLWYP.content:
*You will learn more about using inputs and outputs in the next task, but for now, why not try experimenting with this patch?*

Play around with some pins. E.g. change the led ACT pin, or link a clock node to the button UPD pin and see what happens. See what you can achieve!

HkXMYS8btD.content:
*Your final patch should look like this.*

Congrats! you've now made a simple programme that uses an input (the button) and an output (the led) to affect change.

Bk1J-6nLP.content:
*2. Name the patch *

Type a name for your new patch, e.g. ‘clear’ and click confirm or press the Enter key.

Bks3ga3Uw.content:
*1. Make a new patch *

Add a new patch by clicking the ‘Add patch’ button in the project browser or selecting ‘File > New Patch...’ from the menu.

r1Fcx62UP.content:
Once a programme is loaded onto your board it will remain there and restart whenever you turn on the board. Each time you upload a new programme it will write over the previous programme.

You don't need to clear the board before you upload a new programme, but *if you wish to reset your board you can do this manually by uploading a blank patch in XOD*.

ryWJbT28D.content:
*3. Upload *

Upload the empty patch by clicking the upload button as before. This will turn off the LED and clear the board.

@/tuto201-inputs-and-outputs-adding-a-ne.description:
Start of Task 2: Inputs and Outputs
In this task we will build on our knowledge to add two new devices: the buzzer and the rotary potentiometer.
T2 Step 1: Adding a New Library

H1DHoj6Lw.content:
**Task 2: Inputs and Outputs**
*Adding a New Library*

HkeR0jTLv.content:
*3. Locating the Library*

The library *marcoaita/malibrary* should now appear in the Project Browser.

HyfjssaID.content:
*Great! You now understand the basic principles of using XOD, and can programme your board to control one of the onboard devices: the LED.*

Like the button and the LED, most devices you will use can be grouped into two general categories: inputs and outputs.  

Understanding how to control different inputs and outputs, and how to combine them together is key to making useful devices.  

In this task we will build on our knowledge to add two new devices to our belt. The buzzer and the rotary potentiometer (also known as a knob sensor).

SJS9AspUP.content:
*2. Adding a library*

Add this library by clicking on the ‘Add library’ button (next to the ‘New patch’ button at the top of the Project Browser) or by navigating to ‘File > Add Library...’. Type the full name of the library, and when it appears, click on it to install. If you get an error message asking to install dependencies, accept this.

ryNYjspIP.content:
*1. Finding a buzzer node*

There is no preinstalled node to represent the buzzer. However, several have been created by members of the XOD community. We will use one from the library called marcoaita/malibrary.

SJgk4Jha8w.content:
*We can copy our previous nodes into this patch to save ourselves some work!*

*1.* Select all of the nodes from tuto112 by dragging a box around them.

*2.* Copy them by navigating to 'Edit > Copy' or using Ctrl+C/⌘+C.

*3.* Paste into this patch by navigating to 'Edit > Paste' or using Ctrl+V/⌘+V.

B14DteDWtD.content:
*This time we want to use the buzzer as an output instead of the LED.*

*1. Delete the led node*

Click on the led node and delete it by navigating to 'Edit > Cut' or using the delete or backspace keys on your keyboard.

*2. Add a buzzer node*

Now that the library is installed you can search for the marcoaita/malibrary/ buzzer node and add it as usual.

@/tuto204-set-buzzer-pins-and-reconnect.description: T2 Step 4: Set Buzzer Pins and Reconnect

SyEDRGP-FP.content:
*Now we need to set the pins on this new buzzer node.*

*1. PORT*

The buzzer is connected to port D5, so make sure the PORT pin is set to ‘D5’

*2. FREQ*

The FREQ pin sets the frequency and pitch of the buzzer. You can leave this as 440, or change it too see what happens.

*3. Reconnect*

Connect the not output pin to the buzzer EN (enabled) pin. This will ‘enable’ the buzzer when the button is pressed.

SyrDRfP-Yw.content:
**Task 2: Inputs and Outputs**
*Set Buzzer Pins and Reconnect*

SkmZnXDbKD.content:
*Now try uploading your programme.*

It should work similarly to the LED patch, i.e. the buzzer turns on when you press the button.

@/tuto206-add-a-pot-node-and-set-pins.description: T2 Step 6: Add a Pot Node and Set Pins

B1N5AFuZFD.content:
*Great! Now let’s add a second input.*

We can use the inbuilt rotary potentiometer (knob) to adjust the frequency of the buzzer sound.

To represent the potentiometer we can use the pot node from the xod/common-hardware library.

*1.* Add a pot node to the patch.

*2.* Set PORT pin to 'A0'.

*3.* Set UPD pin to 'Continuously'.

BkrqCtuZtD.content:
**Task 2: Inputs and Outputs**
*Add a Pot Node and Set Pins*

@/tuto207-mapping-values.description: T2 Step 7: Mapping Values: Add and Connect a Map Node

BkE0gtWKw.content:
*1.* Add a map node from xod/math.

*2.* Connect the pot VAL pin to  the map X pin.

*3.* Connect the map output pin to the buzzer FREQ pin.

H14QX9OZtv.content:
*So, how do we connect the pot node to the patch?*

We could connect the pot output VAL (value) pin straight to the FREQ input pin.

However, this wouldn’t work well, as the VAL output ranges between 0 and 1, and frequencies emmited by the buzzer are much higher.

*To get around this, we can add a map node.*

This will ‘map’ your input range to a new output range, so we can change the 0-1 scale of the potentiometer to a larger scale that the buzzer can use.

r1r7Q5_WFD.content:
**Task 2: Inputs and Outputs**
*Mapping Values: Add and Connect a Map Node*

SkSLwZtWKD.content:
*Now we need to set the remaining map input nodes to define our source and target ranges.* 

Smin and Smax set the source range, whilst Tmin and Tmax set the target range.

*1.* Set Smin to ‘0’ and Smax to ‘1’.

*2.* Set Tmin to ‘200’ and Tmax to ‘1000’.

rkDIPZKWFP.content:
*Now try uploading your programme.*

Use the button to turn the buzzer on and off, and the potentiometer to set the frequency.

B1tfadtWFv.content:
*Now try uploading your programme!*

Use the button to turn the buzzer on and off, and use the potentiometer to set the frequency.

Bk5A-Th8v.content:
*Great work! You've now completed Task 1: Testing Your Board!*

You can now move on to Task 2: Inputs and Outputs by opening tuto201.

S1cXWo-vw.content:
**Building Complex Devices**

When building biological devices, you will need to combine a variety of inputs and outputs to create a functioning programme and device. You will often receive inputs, e.g. from an on/off button or sensor, and then use these inputs to create the desired output, e.g. displaying a reading, sending data to a computer or moving a motor.  

The button, buzzer and potentiometer example used here is a very simple example, but the principle applies in more complex systems too. Using XOD allows you to visualise this information flow from input to output, which can be helpful and sometimes more intuitive than traditional text-based coding.

S1jr-o-wP.content:
**Before moving on to tuto301, we suggest reading the introduction to Lesson 3: 'Explore XOD' and 'Tweak and Watch Nodes' in the Beginner's Guide (p32-33).**
*These pages will provide some useful background information to help you with the next tasks.*

rJe9vko-vP.content: *Congrats, you've now completed Task 2: Inputs and Outputs!*

rkBwbjWPw.content:
In the next lesson we’ll be getting a better understanding of what is possible in XOD by exploring a variety of useful nodes and processes using a range of the board’s inbuilt devices.  

When you are ready to explore beyond the starter kit’s capabilities, the No-Code Programming for Biology Handbook explores a variety of common input and output devices which are useful for building biological devices, and explains how they can be programmed using XOD.

@/tuto301-tweak-and-watch-nodes-creating.description:
Start of Task 3: Tweak and Watch Nodes.
In this task we’ll look at how we can use tweak and watch nodes to take readings from another of the inbuilt devices: the temperature and humidity sensor.
T3 Step 1: Creating a New Project

H1El4i-Dw.content:
*Before we start, lets practice saving and creating a new project.*

For this run-through tutorial, we don't actually need to do this, as we'll be carrying on in this project - but it's useful to know how. Once you've completed this step you should reopen this XOD file to continue with tuto302.

First, save this project (you can’t have two projects open at once) by navigating to 'File > Save'.

Then navigate to ‘File > New Project...’ in the menu bar.

Finally, give your project a name. XOD will then open a new blank project.

It's good to keep one project file for each device you are working on, so that your project files don't get to big and messy.

HyxnvGobDv.content:
**Before starting the task, we suggest reading the introduction to Lesson 3: 'Explore XOD' and 'Tweak and Watch Nodes' in the Beginner's Guide (p32-33).**

*In this task we’ll look at how we can use tweak and watch nodes to take readings from another of the inbuilt devices: the temperature and humidity sensor.*

  We’ll be using a tweak-pulse node to act as a button and take a reading whenever we press (or ‘tweak’) it, and watch nodes to display our readings on the computer screen.

 We’ll also be using the ‘Simulate/Debug’ mode in XOD, which lets us to watch and make changes while the code is running.  

This is a great example of how tweak and watch nodes can be used to quickly and easily test a patch. They are very useful for testing and debugging patches, so you should try to get used to using them as you build.

r1hPMi-ww.content:
**Task 3: Tweak and Watch Nodes**
*Creating a New Project*

@/tuto302-add-and-set-hygrometer-node.description: T3 Step 2: Add and Set Hygrometer Node

B1x2V8j-ww.content:
*Let's add a hygrometer node and set it's pins.*

The onboard temperature and humidity sensor is technically known as a DHT11 hygrometer. There is an preinstalled XOD node for this device called dht11-hygrometer.

Add this node to your patch from the xod-dev/dht library.

Set the port pin to ‘D3’

Bk2ELoWww.content:
**Task 3: Tweak and Watch Nodes**
*Add and Set Hygrometer Node*

@/tuto303-add-and-connect-tweak-and-watc.description: T3 Step 3: Add and Connect Tweak and Watch Nodes

BJ1A8s-DD.content:
**Task 3: Tweak and Watch Nodes**
*Add and Connect Tweak and Watch Nodes*

HJg1RIibvD.content:
*Your node should look like this.*

Add a tweak-pulse and two watch nodes from the xod/debug library.

Connect the tweak-pulse node to the UPD pin and a watch node to each of the pins Tc  (temperature ºC) and RH (relative humidity).

H1efrPobDP.content:
**Task 3: Tweak and Watch Nodes**
*Upload and Debug*

Sy7XOjZwD.content:
*Once you've pressed 'Upload and Debug' and the patch has sucessfully uploaded.*

*1. Watch*
Look at the watch node. It won’t display a reading yet because we have set the UPD pin to only update when we tweak it.

*2. 'Tweak' the Node*
Whilst it is still running, click on the tweak node. In the Inspector pane is a button next to OUT that says ‘pulse’. Click it.

*3. Watch Again*
Look at the watch nodes again. This time they should display the current temperature and humidity.

rkZfBPoZvD.content:
*Your patch should now look like this.*

This time, instead of just uploading, we are going to 'upload and debug'. This will allow us to edit and watch the patch in real-time.

Click the ‘Upload and Debug’ button (ladybird) next to the upload button, or use the upload button and tick the box labelled ‘Debug after upload’.

HJTZFs-DP.content:
*Congrats, you've now completed Task 3: Tweak and Watch Nodes*

Hopefully this was a nice simple task to show you how tweak and watch nodes can be useful.

We will use this nodes often throughout the rest of the tutorial, so its good to understand how they work. You can learn more about tweak and watch nodes on the [XOD website](https://xod.io/docs/guide/debugging/).

rkLKktsWPw.content:
**Task 3: Tweak and Watch Nodes**
*End of Task 3*

rkckqjbPw.content:
**Before moving on to tuto401, we suggest reading 'Flip, Clock and Count Nodes' in the Beginner's Guide (p36).**
*This will provide some useful background information for the next task.*

@/tuto401-flip-clock-and-count-nodes-add.description:
Start of Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes.
In this task we’ll be experimenting with flip, clock and count nodes to control the behaviour of the inbuilt LED, making it flash.  
T4 Step 1: Add and Link Nodes

BJxVbjiZwP.content:
**Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes**
*Add and Link Nodes*

Hk4boibwD.content:
**Before starting the task, we suggest reading 'Flip, Clock and Count Nodes' in the Beginner's Guide (p36).**

*In this task we’ll be experimenting with flip, clock and count nodes to control the behaviour of the inbuilt LED, making it flash.  *

The flip and clock nodes can be useful for modifying and timing the behaviour of nodes, whilst the count node can be useful for monitoring these behaviours. In the context of biological devices, these nodes are very useful for fine-tuning devices and for building larger programmes.

Hy8HjobvP.content:
*1. Add the following nodes to this patch:*

tweak-pulse (xod/debug)
flip-n-times (xod/core)
led (xod/common-hardware)

S1w5oo-Pv.content:
*2. Link the nodes as follows:*

Connect the tweak-pulse node to the flip-n-times SET pin.

Connect the flip-n-times OUT pin to the led LUM pin.

Bkyt6oWPP.content:
**Output Pins**

*OUT* (output) reads the current state of the node (true/false).

*Nc* (cycle number) reads the number of times cycled.

*ACT* (active) reads whether the sequence is currently running or not.

*If you’d like to get a better idea of how these outputs work, you can always add watch nodes, to help see what’s going on.*

H15Paobvv.content:
**Input Pins**

*N* (number) sets how many times the sequence will run.

*Ton* (time on) defines the duration of each 'on' state.

*Toff* (time off) defines the duration of each 'off' state.

A pulse to *SET* (set) will start the sequence.

A pulse to *RST* (reset) will reset the node.

HyIP2jbDD.content:
*Your patch should now look like this.*

*Let's look at the flip-n-times node and each of its pins, so that we understand what it does.*

This node defines a sequence that will switch between true and false a set number of times. You can alter this sequence of on/off modes by setting the different input pins. There are also several output pins that allow you to monitor different aspects of the sequence.

SJ81nsZDw.content:
**Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes**
*The Flip-N-Times Node*

S146Ik2bPv.content:
**Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes**
*Setting the Pins*

rJMygnWwv.content:
*2. led pins*

As in tuto103, set the PORT pin to ‘D4’ and the ACT pin to ‘True’.

rkXs13-Pw.content:
*1. flip-n-times pins*

Set N to ‘5’, Ton and Toff to ‘1’, and RST to ‘Never’.

You can also add a tweak-pulse node to the RST pin to test how it works, if you like.

ryrpLk2ZvD.content: *Now let's determine the sequence parameters by setting the node pins.*

BJETBenbvP.content:
**Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes**
*Upload and Debug*

H1HTren-Dw.content:
*Your patch should now look like this*

*Upload and debug this patch using the ladybird button.*

Whilst in debug mode, press the tweak-pulse node and watch what happens to the LED. Each time you press, the light should flash 5 times.

B19BM3bPv.content:
**Output Pins**

*MEM* (memory) reads out the latest state of the node.
*Connect this to the LUM pin of the led.*

Hk4EG-2ZPw.content:
**Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes**
*The Flip-Flop Node*

HkBVGZ3ZvP.content:
*Now lets try a different flip node.*

Delete the flip-n-times node and add a flip-flop node (xod/core).

*Let's look at the flip-flop node, set each of its pins and reconnect the patch.*

The flip-flop node switches between true and false (on and off) states each time it is pulsed.

Hk_qWhZvv.content:
**Input Pins**

*TGL* (toggle) switches the node between true and false each time it receives a pulse.
*Connect the tweak-pulse node to TGL.*

*SET* (set) sets current state to true.
*Set this to ‘On Boot’.*

*RST* (reset) sets current state to false.
*Set this to to ‘Never’.*

B18U5Xh-vw.content:
*Upload and debug the program, and pulse the tweak-pulse node.*

The LED should switch between on and off each time you press it.

r1BU57h-vD.content:
**Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes**
*Upload and Debug (round 2)*

B1Sz5V2bvw.content:
*The flip-flop node can also make the LED flash in sequence, when it is combined with a clock node.*

Add a clock node (xod/core) to the patch.

*Let's look at the clock node, set each of its pins and reconnect the patch.*

The clock node sends pulses at a specific time interval, creating a regular ‘ticking’ of pulses.

By3YrnZvD.content:
**Input Pins**

*EN* (enabled) determines whether the 'ticking' is enabled or not.
*Set this to 'True'.*

*IVAL* (interval) determines how often the clock ticks (in secs).
*Set this to ‘1’.*

*RST* (reset) resets the clock.
*Set this to ‘Never’.*

HJe3KBnWPP.content:
**Output Pins**

*TICK* (tick) pulses at the end of each interval (set by the IVAL pin).
*Delete the tweak-pulse node and connect the clock node in its place by linking the TICK pin to the TGL pin.*

SkVf5Nh-vw.content:
**Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes**
*The Clock Node*

Bkwnd83WPv.content:
**Input Pins**

*INC* (increase) increases the count each time it recieves a pulse or True signal.
*Connect the led DONE pin to the clock INC pin.*
The led DONE pin pulses each time the LED turns on or off, so we can count how many times the led switches.

*STEP* (step) determines how much the count increases by with each pulse.
*Set this to ‘1’.*

*RST* (reset) resets the count to 0.
*Set this to ‘Never’.*

ByBnu82ZPD.content:
**Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes**
*The Count Node*

ByU2OI2ZPP.content:
*We’ll also add a count node to this patch so that we can monitor the number of times the LED flashes.*

Add a count node (xod/core).

*Let's look at the count node, set each of its pins and connect it to the patch.*

The count node measures how many times a pulse or boolean ‘True’ signal has been sent, counting up each time it recieves a signal.

S1uhuL2WPv.content:
**Output Pins**

*Add a watch node and connect it to the clock output pin*
This setup will let us see on the screen each time the LED pulses.

B1Bd6dhbPv.content:
*Your patch should now look something like this.*

Upload and debug the program. Watch the LED and your watch node.

The LED should flash and the count will increase with each switch.

H1Nd6unZvv.content:
**Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes**
*Upload and Debug (round 3)*

SJxxOF2ZvP.content:
As with all programming, there is always more than one way to achieve a similar outcome, and different methods may suit different applications. Here we have tested two different ways of making the LED flash, but there are plenty of other ways you can experiment with. 

*Why not try using a square-wave node to make the LED flash?*
See if you can work it out using the help pane and [XOD website](https://xod.io/libs/xod/waves/square-wave/?utm_source=ide&utm_campaign=docs&utm_medium=inspector).

*Or you can just try playing around with the nodes you’ve already tried.*
Try experimenting with different timings and patterns of flashing.

**If you need to, you can copy nodes from previous patches into this patch by dragging a box around the nodes you want, then copy-and-pasting.**

ByuWHp-PD.content:
*Great, you've now completed Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes*

These nodes are really useful for controlling and monitoring the sequence of your programmes.

Additionaly, we have been introduced to a few useful skills:

*1. Combining count and watch nodes*
Combining these nodes (like we did in tuto409) is a really useful way to visualise the output of a pulse pin. You can learn more about this trick by reading 'Watching Pulse Pins:  Combining Count and Watch Nodes' in the Beginner's Guide (p35).

*2. Discovering new nodes*
The last step of this task (tuto410) encourages you to try out a new node: the square-wave node. We have not provided specific information about this node here, but it is useful to practice discovering new nodes for yourself. You can learn more about the different ways to do this by reading 'Discovering New Nodes' in the Beginner's Guide (p35).

HkxuZHabDw.content:
**Before moving on to tuto501, we suggest reading 'Concat, Join and  Format-Number Nodes' in the Beginner's Guide (p42).**
*This will provide some useful background information for the next task.*

SJWySaWPD.content:
**Task 4: Flip, Clock and Count Nodes**
*End of Task 4*

@/tuto501-concat-join-and-format-number-.description:
Start of Task 5: Concat, Join and Format-Number Nodes.
In this task we’ll look at using concat, join and format-number nodes. We will use the Grove air pressure sensor module to test these nodes.
T5 Step 1: Barometer-Thermometer Node

B1Bnw6Zvv.content:
**Task 5: Concat, Join and  Format-Number Nodes**
*Barometer-Thermometer Node*

H1O9KaZPw.content:
*2. Add node*

Add a barometer-thermometer node from this library to the patch.

H1q9KTbvw.content:
*3. Set node*

Set UPD to ‘Continuously’. Leave other inputs as they are.

The outputs of this node are temperature (TEMP) and pressure (PRESS).

To learn more about what each of the input and output pins does, click on the node and open the quick help pane (question mark button in the top right corner).

HJeHhwa-ww.content:
**Before starting the task, we suggest reading 'Concat, Join and  Format-Number Nodes' in the Beginner's Guide (p42).**

*In this task we’ll look at using concat, join and format-number nodes. These nodes are especially useful when working with data and displays.  *

The concat and join nodes are both used to combine information in the form of strings (text). The format-number node is used to set the number of decimal points displayed in a number. In combination, these nodes are useful for formatting the outputs of sensor modules, both for data storage, and for display on a screen.

SkXYKaWwv.content:
*1. Add library*

To work with the air pressure sensor (also known as a barometer) you will need to install the library wayland/bmp280-barometer (as in tuto201).

SyaIO6bPP.content: *Let's start by adding a barometer-thermometer node, so that we can use the Grove air pressure   sensor.*

B1xrVqabDP.content:
*Now let's add and set a concat node.*

*1.* Add a concat node (xod/core).

This node combines multiple strings from the input pins into a single output.

This node is ‘variadic’ meaning you can expand the node by pulling on the tab on the right, letting you increase the number of inputs. Give this a try. Then reduce it back to two inputs.

*2.* Connect the first input to the barometer-thermometer TEMP pin.

*3.* Set the second input to ‘oC’ (degrees centigrade) using the inspector pane .

rJrE9pWwv.content:
**Task 5: Concat, Join and  Format-Number Nodes**
*Concat Node*

rkXFssTZwv.content:
*Your patch should now look like this.*

*Next, we'll add and set a format-number node.*

*1.* Add a format-number node (xod/core).

This node lets you format the number of decimal places in a number.

*2.* Link the barometer-thermometer PRESS (pressure) pin to the format-number NUM (number) pin.

*3.* Set DIG (digits) to ‘0’ decimal places.

ryGtjjpbvw.content:
**Task 5: Concat, Join and  Format-Number Nodes**
*Format-Number Node*

HJf-dn6-vw.content:
**Task 5: Concat, Join and  Format-Number Nodes**
*Join Node*

Sk7bd2pZvw.content:
*Now we'll add and set a join node.*

*1.* Add a join node (xod/core).

This is similar to concat, but  has a D (deliminator) pin. D determines how inputs are joined (e.g. via a space or colon).

It’s automatically set to be a space. Leave it as this.

*2.* Connect the first input (S1) to the format-number STR (string) pin.

*3.* Set the second input to ‘Pa’ (pascals, the unit of air pressure) using the inspector pane.

@/tuto505-add-watch-nodes-upload-and-deb.description: T5 Step 5: Add Watch Nodes, Upload and Debug

B14tY6pbvD.content:
**Task 5: Concat, Join and  Format-Number Nodes**
*Add Watch Nodes, Upload and Debug*

SyHKKTTZvw.content:
*Your patch should now look like this.*

*Finally, we can add watch nodes, upload and debug the patch.*

*1.* Add two watch nodes (xod/debug).

*2.* Link one to the output of the concat node, and one to the output of the join node.

You may need to expand the watch nodes by pulling on the bottom right corner.

*3.* Upload and debug using the ladybird button.

Look at the watch nodes and notice how the two values are displayed.

H1e3ky0WwD.content:
*Play around with the nodes in your patch to see how you can format the sensor output in different ways.*

*Try exploring other nodes available for formatting numbers in XOD.*

For example, number-split-to-digit (from the gst/number-split-to-digit library), dec-to-2digits or dec-to-4digits (both from the cesars/utils library). You may need to install these libraries first.

HygJUrRWDv.content:
*You've now completed Task 5: Concat, Join and  Format-Number Nodes, well done!*

This section has covered a number of basic nodes that we have found useful in building simple biological devices. However, there are plenty of other useful nodes out there, both pre-installed in XOD, and created by XOD users such as yourself.

  In the rest of this tutorial we will continue to explore useful nodes and techniques in XOD, but if you’d like to explore for yourself, here are a few useful resources for getting to grips with XOD:  

*XOD Tutorial *
Each time you open XOD it will offer you the option of following its inbuilt tutorial. Working through this is a great way to learn more about what XOD can do. It is also available on the XOD website under [Tutorial](www.xod.io/docs/tutorial).

*  XOD Guide*
The XOD user guide provides advice on some more complex concepts, as well as some case studies to work through. It is available on the XOD website under [Guide](www.xod.io/docs/guide).

*  XOD Core Library*
 Taking a look through the nodes in the XOD core library will help you understand the most basic nodes available and what they do. Find xod/core in the Project Browser.

SJk4BAWPD.content:
**Task 5: Concat, Join and  Format-Number Nodes**
*End of Task 5*

SyvXZZGDD.content:
**Before moving on to tuto601, we suggest reading the introduction to Lesson 4: 'Building Devices' and 'Creating New Nodes' in the Beginner's Guide (p48-49).**
*These pages will provide some useful background information to help you with the next tasks.*

@/tuto601-creating-new-nodes-making-a-wr.description:
Start of Task 6: Creating New Nodes
In this task we’ll learn how to make a new node that will allow us to write text on our OLED screen, using readings from the sound sensor.
T6 Step 1: Making a 'Write-Text-To-Oled' Patch

r15pWZGPP.content:
**Before starting the task,  we suggest reading the introduction to Lesson 4: 'Building Devices' and 'Creating New Nodes' in the Beginner's Guide (p48-49).**

*In this task we’ll learn how to make a new node that will allow us to write text on our OLED screen.*

  Instructing the OLED screen to display text is a slightly more complex task that we have done so far, and involves several nodes to represent the screen rather than one.

In this task we’ll be combining these multiple nodes into one, which we will then use to display the readings from our onboard sound sensor.  

Creating your own nodes is much easier than it sounds. It is essentially the same as creating any other patch, but we need to add special nodes called ‘terminals’ to allow our new node to communicate with other nodes.

Creating nodes like this is useful as it helps to simplify the patch, and we can also save new nodes for later use in different programmes.

You can switch back and forth between the tutorial patches and your 'write-text-to-oled' patch using the tabs at the top of the screen.

If you have not done so already, now might be a good time to close some of the old tutorial patches so that you have less tabs to keep track of.

Hk_ZPZfPP.content:
*2. rotate-display  *

You can change the screen orientation using this node. 

Set *ROT* (rotation state) to ‘02h’, which is correct for our screen.

Set *UPD* (update) to ‘On Boot’ so that the screen updates when the programme starts.

This node starts a sequence that allows us to display items on the screen. *In this sequence, each DONE pin connects to the next UPD pin.*

Connect the *rotate-screen DONE* pin to the *clear-display UPD* pin.

Hy7bDWfPv.content:
*1. ssd1306-oled-i2c-device  *

This node represents the OLED device.

*WIDTH* and *HEIGHT* set the dimensions of the screen in pixels. Leave these as ‘128’ and ‘64’.

*ADDRESS* identifies the port, leave this as ‘3Ch’. 

*RESET* represents the screen’s reset pin. Leave this as ‘-1’, as our board does not have a dedicated screen reset pin.

*The output of this node, DEV (device) needs to be connected to each of the other nodes' DEV input pins.*

*TEXT* is where you enter your text. Use ‘Hello!’ as a test.

*SIZE* determines the size of the text. Leave this as ‘02h’.

*COLOUR* determines the colour of the text (black or white). Set this to ‘1’.

*WRAP* determines whether the text is wrapped within the boundaries of the screen. Leave this as ‘True”.

Connect the *DONE* pin to the *send-buffer-to-display UPD* pin.

ryuIkMGDv.content:
*Your 'write-text-to-oled' patch should now look like this*

Writing a line of text directly to the OLED screen is great, but what if we need a more complicated node? For example, one that takes multiple lines of text, or one that sends a signal once the text has been uploaded?

Lets make some more edits to our 'write-text-to-display' node to add in these capabilities.

An annoted version of the modifed patch is available in the Beginner's Guide, on page 47. It may be useful to have this to hand when completing this task.

**In your 'write-text-to-oled' patch:**

*1. Second draw-text node  *

Add a second draw-text node below the first. We will use this to draw a second line of text. Set the Y pin of this node to 20. This will move the text down by 20 pixels, creating a new line.

*2.  Reconnect*

  Delete the link between the first draw-text node and send-buffer-to-display. Link the first draw-text DONE pin to the second draw-text UPD pin. Link the second draw-text DONE pin to the send-buffer-to-display UPD pin. Connect ssd1306-oled-i2c-device DEV to the second draw-text DEV pin.

*3.   Label input-string nodes*

Add a second input-string node and connect it to the TEXT pin of the second draw-text node. We will now have more than one input into our node, so we need give them labels, to avoid confusion. Click on each input-string node in turn. Use the Inspector pane to name your nodes by typing in the ‘Label’ text box. Name your nodes ‘LINE 1’ and ‘LINE 2’ respectively.  

*4. Add output-string node*

  Add an output-pulse node to the patch, and connect it to the send-buffer-to-display DONE pin. Use the Inspector to label this node ‘DONE’.

If you are having trouble, compare your 'write-text-to-oled' patch to the example in tuto607 to check that it's set up correctly.

SkhXm1PDw.content:
*Great job! You've now completed Task 6: Creating New Nodes!*

One of the great advantages of XOD is the growing community of contributors, who are generating an ever-expanding range of nodes and libraries for other to use. When you create new nodes that you think might be useful for others, you can easily share these with the XOD community by publishing them as a library.

*Learn more about how to share nodes and publish libraries on page 49 of the Beginner's Guide.*

When publishing your work it is good practice to make sure that your nodes are well documented. This helps to remind yourself what you’ve done, and allows others to get an idea of how the node can be used.

H1gAPIkDPv.content:
**Before starting the task, we suggest reading 'Sharing Nodes and Publishing Libraries' and 'Documenting Nodes' in the Beginner's Guide (p55).**

*In this task we’ll look at another way to simplify our patches: using buses.*

*Buses are a way to link pins ‘invisibly’ so that you don’t have too many link intersections that make the data flow confusing.*

  Buses are a little like input and output nodes. They come in two types, to-bus and from-bus, and they automatically take the data type of the pin they’re connected to.

 The to-bus node is used like an output node and sends information from an output to a bus. The from-bus node acts like an input node and retrieves information from the bus of the same name.  

We’ll practice using buses by displaying the output of our 3-axis acceleration sensor (also known as an accelerometer or tilt sensor) on our OLED screen.

ryy8DkPPP.content:

Hk6iY1DPw.content:
*4. Replace links with buses*

  Although the OLED patch worked, it was very messy, with links criss-crossing, and it would be easy to miss a connection. Let’s improve this by replacing these links with a bus. First, delete all of the orange links between the ssd1306-oled-i2c-device and the other nodes. Add a to-bus node (xod/patch-nodes) and link it to the output of ssd1306-oled-i2c-device. Use the inspector to label this node ‘DEV’. Add a from-bus node (xod/patch-nodes). Make sure this from-bus node is also labelled ‘DEV’ as buses can only communicate if they have the same name. Repeat this process, or copy and paste the DEV from-bus node until you have four in total. Connect these to each of the DEV input pins on the nodes rotate-display, clear-display, draw-circle and send-buffer-to-display.

HkJV85e0D.content:
*3. Greater*

 The greater node is very similar to the less node, but it will return ‘True’ only when the first input is greater than the second input.

Repeat the same connections for the greater node: connect a *from-bus* node to the first input and label it ‘VAL’. Then connect a *tweak-number* node to the second input to let you tweak the upper limit.

SJ0HvqlAD.content:
*4. Nor*

The nor node will only return ‘True’ if both inputs read ‘False’.

We want a third state that triggers if the light intensity is *neither less than the lower limit, nor greater than the upper limit*, and we will use the nor node to achieve this.

Connect the output of less node to the first nor input, and the output of the greater node to the second nor input.

rkWs6ltx0w.content:
*2. Less*

This node takes the first input value and compares it to the second input value.

It will return ‘True’ if the first value is less than the second, and ‘False’ if not.

Connect one of the *from-bus* nodes to the first input and label it ‘VAL’ so it receives the value output by the multiply node.

Connect one of the *tweak-number* nodes to the second input so you can tweak the lower limit later.

Sk-6lYceRP.content:
*2. If-else*

The if-else node will output one value (T) if the condition (COND) it receives is true, and another (F) if it is False.

We want to set up the three if-else nodes so that each of the above conditions (less than the lower limit, greater than the upper limit, or neither) returns as different line of text.

  Set the T pin of the first if-else node to ‘too dim’ and connect the COND pin to the less output.
Set the T pin of the second if-else node to ‘all ok’ and connect the COND pin to the nor output.
Set the T pin of the third if-else node to ‘too bright’ and connect the COND pin to the greater output.

We will leave the F pins blank, so that nothing is returned when the conditions are false.

SyuY55l0D.content:
*3. Concat*

Use the tab on the variadic concat node to expand it to three inputs.

Connect all three of the if-else outputs to the concat inputs.

This will combine all three responses into one string. Due to the logic conditions, only one string will be returned at a time and each of the other two nodes will return a blank value.

Connect the *to-bus* node to the concat output and label it ‘STATE’.

*4. Watch Nodes*

Connect a *from-bus* node to each watch node.

Label one ‘VAL’ and one ‘STATE’. This will link one to the 100x multiplied output of the sensor node so that you can see the sensor reading, and one to the final output of the concat node so that you can see the current state.

By adding buses here we can put the two watch nodes together and easily view the outputs side by side, rather than having to move around the screen.

If you like, you can also add additional watch nodes and buses to monitor other aspects of the programme. For example, you can add buses to the outputs from the less, greater and nor nodes, the if-else nodes, or even the raw sensor reading to monitor these readings alongside the 'VAL' and 'STATE' outputs.

Change the light intensity by moving or covering the board. Watch how this affects the output displayed on the screen.

BJGzS2gRD.content:
We have now covered a number of logic nodes including: not (tuto111), nor (tuto804) and if-else (tuto806), as well as several useful matematical operators, such as: round (tuto705), multiply (tuto802), less (tuto804), greater (tuto804).

*Explore some of the other logic and opertaor nodes from the xod/core library.* 
Such as and, any, nand, or, xor, equal, add, subtract and divide.

rJjNY2gAv.content:
*Or try using if-else to control a programme’s timing.*
By combining the if-else node with a pulse-on-true or pulse-on-false node, you can use it to control your programe and initiate different sequences under different conditions - a very useful skill!

*When you're ready, move on to tuto901 to start the next task.*

@/tuto901-sequences-and-loops-create-new.description:
Start of Task 9: Sequences and Loops.
In this final task we’ll explore one of the most useful skills for building biological devices: creating sequences and loops. This task will introduce these skills by using the buzzer to play a simple tune - hot cross buns.
T9 Step 1: Create New Patches

SJZOGBq4Cv.content:
*Make three new patches.*

Add three new patches to the project, and name them ‘bar124’, ‘bar3’ and 'play-tune'.

As with the last few tasks, we'll be moving back and forth between the tutorial patches and these new patches, so make sure they are easily accessible in the tabs at the top of the screen.

ryOMBqVAP.content:
*In this final task we’ll explore one of the most useful skills for building biological devices: creating sequences and loops.  *

By programming a sequence of events, using logic and introducing loops we can make devices that are useful for tasks such as automation, monitoring and response to environmental conditions. 

This task will introduce these skills by using the buzzer to play a simple tune - hot cross buns.

  This will involve creating two separate sequences and using logic nodes to instruct the programme when to play them. We will use two different methods to make the sequences, and will create a separate node for each one.

@/tuto904-set-up-your-bar124-node.description: T9 Step 4: Set Up Your Bar 124 Node

BJPjd9ERw.content:
**Task 9: Sequences and Loops**
*Set Up Your Bar124 Node*

H1Y1KcNAD.content:
*1. Buzzer-timed nodes*

  Set each of the buzzer-timed nodes to play a different note by changing their frequency pins:
- Set one to ‘246.94’ Hz and change it’s name to ‘B’ using the label field in the Inspector.
- Set one to ‘220’ Hz and name it ‘A’.
- Set one to ‘196’ Hz and name it ‘G’.

Set PORT to ‘D5’ and EN to ‘False’ on all three.

Set T (time) to ‘1’ on B and A and to ‘2’ on G. This will produce a longer final note.

Connect the nodes in sequence:
- Connect the DONE pin of B to the SET pin of A
- Connect the DONE pin of A to the SET pin of G
- Add the output-pulse node to the DONE pin of G and name it ‘DONE’, so that we can see when the sequence is complete.

H1m6dqERw.content:
*In the bar124 patch we will create the sequence of notes (B, A, G) that make up bars 1, 2 and 4 of the tune.*

To make this easier, you can copy each of the comment boxes in this patch into the bar124 patch, or you can complete the steps in this patch, and copy them over to the bar124 patch when you are done.

HkE155VAw.content:
*2. Count  *

Connect the DONE pin of G to the INC pin of count so that the count increases each time the sequence is complete. 

Add the output-number node to the output pin and name it ‘RND’ (round), so that we can see the number of times the sequence has played.

Add an input-pulse node to the RST (reset) button and name it ‘RST’. We will use this to reset the count when the tune finishes.

rJnzc5N0P.content:
*3. Delay*

    We will use the delay node to introduce a half second gap between each bar.

Set T (time) to 0.5.

Connect the DONE pin of delay to the SET pin of B.

Add an input-pulse node to the SET pin of delay and name it ‘SET’. We will use this input to initiate the sequence.

@/tuto905-test-the-bar124-node.description: T9 Step 5: Test the Bar124 Node

BkZfscEAP.content:
**Task 9: Sequences and Loops**
*Test the Bar124 Node*

HkxWGs9E0P.content:
*Your bar124 node should now look something like this*

To test this node, you can add a tweak-pulse node to the SET pin of delay.

Upload and debug the patch, then use the tweak-pulse node to initiate the sequence.

@/tuto906-set-up-your-bar3-node-round-1.description: T9 Step 6: Set Up Your Bar3 Node (round 1)

B1Wyi5VRD.content:
*In the bar3 patch we will create the sequence of notes (G x 4, A x 4) that makes up bar 3 of the tune.*

The bar 124 patch uses a series of nodes with connected SET and DONE pins to create a sequence, similar to how we created our write-text-to-oled node in Task 6 (tuto603). The patch for bar 3 will create a sequence in a slightly different way.

First we will set up a sequence to time the notes, then we will use logic nodes to control the frequency and number of the notes. This will create a loop that feeds information coming out of the programme back into the sequence. We will use buses to connect the two halves of this node.

Follow the 5 steps below to set up the first half of the bar3 patch. To avoid switching between patches you can copy each of the comment boxes in this patch into the bar3 patch. Or you can complete the steps in this patch, and copy them over to the bar3 patch when you are done.

S1RgLj4CD.content:
*2. Count*

  Connect the buzzer-timed DONE pin to the count INC pin, so the the count increases each time the buzzer sounds.

Add an input-pulse node to the RST pin and name it ‘RST-BEAT’. We will use this to reset the count at the end.

SJl-Jic4AP.content:
**Task 9: Sequences and Loops**
*Set Up Your Bar3 Node (round 1)*

rJIBIi4AP.content:
*3.   Defer  *

The defer node is the key to creating loops in XOD.

In this case, we are creating a loop that reads out  the beat number, and changes the frequency of the note and decides whether to repeat based on this.

Connect the count output pin to the defer input pin to inform XOD of this loop.

Add a to-bus node to the output pin and name it ‘COUNT’. This will feed into our logic nodes.

rkW-yi5V0P.content:
*1. Buzzer-timed*

Set the port to ‘D5’ and EN to ‘False’.

Set T (time) to 0.5.

Add a from-bus node to the FREQ pin and name it ‘FREQ’. This will allow our logic nodes to set the frequency of the note depending on the beat number.

rkXXIsNRv.content:
*4. Clock  *

We want the buzzer to sound a short note repeatedly. 

To do this, connect the clock node to the buzzer-timed SET pin.

Set RST to ‘On Boot’.

Set the IVAL (interval) pin to 0.51, which is slightly longer than the buzzer sounding time.

ryN6LoN0v.content:
*5.   Or*

  Using the clock node we’ve made the buzzer sound regularly, but we don’t want it to sound all the time. We need to add conditions specifying when the clock is enabled.

The buzzer should sound EITHER at the start of the third bar, OR when the sequence has started but not yet finished, i.e. after beats 1-7, but not after beat 8.

Connect the or node to the EN pin of the clock node. 

Add an input-pulse node to one of the input pins and name it ‘SET’. We will use this to initiate the sequence at the start of bar 3.

Add a from-bus node to the other input pin and name it ‘BEAT’. This will continue the sequence after beats 1-7.

@/tuto907-check-your-bar3-node-round-1.description: T9 Step 7: Check Your Bar3 Node (round 1)

B1On_j4AD.content:
**Task 9: Sequences and Loops**
*Check Your Bar3 Node (round 1)*

SygdndsNAD.content:
*Your bar3 node should now look something like this*

You have added buses that currently don't have any counterparts. This causes an error in XOD, and you may see the bus nodes outlined in red and an exclamation point next to the name of the patch warning you of this.

Don't worry we will use these buses in the next part to link to the other half of the bar3 patch. This will complete the loop that we have started.

@/tuto908-set-up-your-bar3-node-round-2.description: T9 Step 8: Set Up Your Bar3 Node (round 2)

BJ19ci4CD.content:
*3. Round  *

This part records when the sequence is finished.

Connect a from-bus node to the first input pin of the equal node and name it ‘COUNT’. Set the second equal input pin to ‘8’.

Connect the output pin to the count INC pin so that the count increases when the sequence is done. 

Connect the input-pulse node to the count RST pin and name it ‘RST-RND’. We will use this to reset the count at the end.

Add the output-number node to the count output and name it ‘RND’ so that we can see the number of times the sequence has played.

Connect the pulse-on-true node to the equal output and then add the output-pulse node and name it ‘DONE’. This will let us see when the sequence is complete.

BJMx4uiE0v.content:
*2. Beat*

  This part enables the buzzer pulse after beats 1-7. 

Use the second between node.

Add a from-bus node to X and name it ‘COUNT’.

Set MIN to ‘1’ and MAX to ‘7’.

Add a to-bus node to the output pin and name it ‘BEAT’. This will feed back into the loop as one of the conditions that will enable the clock.

BJleNus4Rv.content:
**Task 9: Sequences and Loops**
*Set Up Your Bar3 Node (round 2)*

SkeEdsN0D.content:
*Follow the 3 steps below to complete the second half of the loop.*

To avoid switching between patches you can copy the comment boxes into the bar3 patch, or visa versa.

SyZgVdsN0w.content:
*1. Frequency*

  This part switches the note between G and A depending on the count number.

Use one of the between nodes. Add a from-bus node to the X pin and name it ‘COUNT’ so that it receives the count number from the end of our sequence.

Set MIN to ‘0’ and MAX to ‘3’. Connect the output to the COND pin of the if-else node.

Set T to ‘196’ so that the buzzer plays a G for the first four notes (count between 0-3). Set F to ‘220’ so that the buzzer plays an A otherwise.

Add a to-bus node to the if-else output pin and name it ‘FREQ’. This will feed back into the loop to set the FREQ pin of the buzzer-timed node.

@/tuto911-set-up-your-play-tune-patch.description: T9 Step 11: Set Up Your Play-Tune Patch

HkVEQhNRv.content:
*Follow the steps below to set up your play-tune patch.*

To avoid switching between patches you can copy the comment boxes into the play-tune patch, or visa versa.

HklVN7nE0D.content:
**Task 9: Sequences and Loops**
*Set Up Your Play-Tune Patch*

S1HCB2E0w.content:
*3. Playing bars 2 and 4.*

We also want to initiate bar124 at the end of bars 1 and 3.

Use two equal nodes. Connect a from-bus node to the first input of each and name them both ‘RND’ so that they receive the round number.

Set the second input of one to ‘1’ and the other to ‘3’.

Connect the outputs of both nodes to the input pins of the or node.

Add a to-bus node to the output of or and name it ‘BAR124’.

Add a from-bus node to the other any input. Name it ‘BAR124’. This will set the bar124 sequence after bars 1 and 3.

Skx3L2NAv.content:
*5. Resetting the sequence.*

After round 4 we want to reset the sequence so that the round count returns to 0.

We added RST pins to our bar124 and bar3 nodes for this reason.

Add a from-bus node to the first input of the final equal node and name it ‘RND’.

Set the second input to ‘4’ so the reset happens after bar 4.

Add a to-bus node to the output pin and name it ‘RST’.

Name both from-bus nodes ‘RST’. Add one to the RST pin of bar124 and one to the RST pins (RST-RND, RST-BEAT) of bar3. This bus will reset the sequence after bar 4 has been played.

SyluEhNCv.content:
*2. Playing bar 1.*

We will use the button on the board to initiate round 1.

Set the button PORT pin to ‘D6’ and PRS pin to ‘True’. Then connect the PRS pin to the not node.

Connect the not output to one of the inputs of any. Leave the other any input unconnected for now.

Add a to-bus node to the not output pin and name it ‘SET’.

Add a from-bus node to the SET pin of bar124 and name it 'SET'. This bus will initiate the bar124 sequence.

r10LLn4Av.content:
*4. Playing bar 3.*

We want bar3 to play at the end of bar 2.

Add a from-bus node to the input of the third equal node and name it ‘RND’.

Set the second input of equal to 2.

Add a to-bus node to the output and name it ‘BAR3’.

Add a from-bus node to the SET pin of bar3 and name it ‘BAR3’. This bus will initiate bar3 after bar 2.

rk9vN3ERw.content:
*1. Counting the round number.*

To start we need to know the current round number. Remember that we added an output pin (RND) to each of our nodes to count how many times it has been played.

Connect both of these RND pins to the add node to sum these two values and find the total round number.

We will be creating a feedback loop again, so add a defer node to the add output.

Then add a to-bus node to this and name it ‘RND’.

ryVQYbwed.content:
*Congratulations, you’ve completed the final task!*

Play around with this patch and the nodes you have used. Try creating a different tune. Or try to make the LED flash along in time with the notes. The possibilities are endless now that you understand the core principles.

*Comment Boxes: why not try adding comment boxes to your play-tune patch?*

When creating a more complex programme like this it is often useful to include comment boxes, both to help keep track of what you are doing, and to make it easier for others to follow your workflow. This is the XOD equivalent of ‘commenting out’ notes when writing code.

In the example below you can see that comments have been added above each section of the programme to describe what that part of the patch is doing. Try adding your comments to annotate your play-tune patch. You can add a comment box by navigating to ‘Edit > Insert Comment” in the menu bar. 

You can also add formatting to your XOD comment boxes, for example: 
- *Surround text with stars to add bold white text* 
- **Surround text with two stars to add bold red text** 
- Use a dash before text to add a bullet list 
1. Use a number and point before text to add a number list  

You can read more about adding comments to document your nodes and XOD ‘markdown’ (formatting) on the [XOD website](www.xod.io/docs/guide/documenting-nodes).

**Before finishing this tutorial, we suggest reading the final chapter of the Beginner's Guide, 'Lesson 5: Next Steps' (p74-93).**
*This chapter will provide some useful information about how to apply your new found skills to creating biological devices.*
